_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the facility:



This facility complies with NFPA-58 requirements for LP-Gas storage. It is the policy of the facility to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws. If an emergency were to occur, the City of Tacoma Fire Department will be notified and requested to respond. It is not anticipated that facility personnel will provide emergency response.



A description of the facility and the regulated substances handled:



The SeaPort Sound Terminal is a bulk terminal storing LPG for wholesale distribution. The facility consists of three 60,000-gallon tanks and track space for up to two 30,000 gallon railcars.



The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:



This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule, the OSHA PSM standard, and all applicable state and local codes and regulations. The propane system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with NFPA-58 and state law. In addition, the facility has evaluated the impacts of a "worst-case" release scenario as well as several alternative releases.



Five-year accident history:



The facility has never had an accident involving propane that caused or could reasonably have resulted in deaths, injuries, property, or environmental damage or evacuations.



The emergency response program:



In the event of an emergency involving the propane system, the policy in place at the facility is to notify the City of Tacoma Fire Department and request that they help respond to the emergency. Response actions have been coordinated with the fire department initially and members of the fire department have inspected our propane system.



Planned changes to improve safety:



The facility adheres to and goes beyond the requirements and timelines established in the PSM/RMP standards. The facility ensures that operating procedures are reviewed annually, operators are trained in the

ir duties initially and provided refresher training at no more than 3 year intervals, and that equipment is maintained in accordance with accepted standards. In addition, compliance audits of the program are completed every three years and PHA revalidations occur every 5 years to ensure that policies are being followed correctly and that the system is being operated and maintained safely. Employees are encouraged to report any potentially safety concerns they may have. Response actions are coordinated with the City of Tacoma Fire Department at least annually.
